title: 111_s3660
content: The Act titled "National Monument Designation Transparency and Accountability Act of 2010" limits the designation of national monuments under the Antiquities Act of 1906. The President's authority to designate national monuments is amended by this Act. The Act "National Monument Designation Transparency and Accountability Act of 2010" amends the President's authority to designate national monuments under the Antiquities Act of 1906. The Act sets requirements for the designation of national monuments, including a 30-day waiting period before proclamation. The Act sets requirements for the designation of national monuments, including a 30-day waiting period before proclamation and public participation through hearings. The Secretary must hold a public hearing within a county or local government unit affected by a proposed national monument, providing notice 30 days in advance through local newspapers and written notices to stakeholders. Public participation and comments are encouraged during the hearing. The Secretary must ensure public participation in a hearing held to discuss a proposed national monument, solicit comments from the public, and include all comments in the record. The record of the hearing must be made available soon after the hearing date. The Secretary must make the record of a public hearing on a proposed national monument available to the public online or through electronic means. The Secretary may waive the public hearing if all local and tribal governments agree. The Secretary may waive a public hearing for a proposed national monument if all local and tribal governments agree. Within 30 days of the President issuing a proclamation, a notice and comment period will be initiated. A report must be submitted to Congress within 1 year of the proclamation. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 1 year of the proclamation, analyzing the economic impact and energy security effects of the national monument designation. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 1 year of the proclamation, analyzing the economic impact and energy security effects of the national monument designation, including the loss of sites for wind, geothermal, or solar energy production, and the impact on oil, coal, and natural gas availability. The report should also assess the projected impact on interests, rights, and uses associated with the land within the monument boundary. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 1 year of the national monument designation, analyzing economic impact, energy security effects, and potential loss of sites for energy production. The report should also assess impacts on interests, rights, and land uses within the monument boundary, including water rights, hunting, grazing, timber production, vegetation maintenance, off-road vehicle use, hiking, horseback riding, and mineral and energy leases. Coordination is required for the report preparation. The report under clause (i) must be prepared in coordination with governing bodies as per the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. The President is responsible for ensuring that components of the report are published on the White House website during compilation and the completed report is submitted to Congress. The Secretary, in cooperation with the States, will develop guidelines for implementing the proclamation. A proclamation issued by the President will expire in 2 years unless approved by Congress. The President must ensure that any restrictions on land designated as a national monument are necessary for proper care and management of the protected objects. If Congress does not approve the proclamation, any land reservation made will not be valid. The President must ensure that any restrictions on land designated as a national monument are necessary for proper care and management of the protected objects. Any reservation of land and restrictions imposed by a proclamation will cease to be effective after 2 years. The President is prohibited from issuing a similar proclamation without Congressional approval. The proclamation designating land as a national monument must be necessary for proper care and management of protected objects. This does not affect limitations on designations in Alaska or Wyoming.
